div1.head: INDEX
div1.p: References are to Book and Section; all dates, given in parentheses (...), are B.C.

div2.head: Academicians
div2.p: 1. adherents of the New Academy (q.v.); their right to teach ethics, 1.6.

div2.head: Academy
div2.p: 1. the Older, a school of philosophy founded by Plato and so called from its home; their doctrine of ideas, 3.76, 81.
the pre-existence and immortality of the soul; monotheism; the goodness of God; striving after His perfection. 2.
the New, a modification of the Old, sceptical, anti-dogmatic, eclectic, 3.20.

div2.head: Lucius Accius
div2.p: a tragic poet (born 170). His tragedies were mostly imitations from the Greek. Cicero knew him personally; quotes from him, 3.84, 102, 106.

div2.head: Gaius Acilius Glabrio
div2.p: (tribune, 197); interpreter, when Carneades, Diogenes, and Critolaus came to Rome; author of History of Rome, 3.115.

div2.head: Aeacidae
div2.p: descendants of Aeacus (q.v.), the father of Peleus and Telamon and grandfather of Achilles and Ajax, 1.38.

div2.head: Aeacus
div2.p: son of Zeus (Jupiter) and king of Aegina (q.v.); renowned for his justice and piety, 1.97.
after his death he became with Minos and Rhadamanthus judge in Hades.

div2.head: Aegina
div2.p: an island in the Saronic Gulf, a dangerous rival to Athens, directly in front of Piraeus and only twelve miles away, 3.46.

div2.head: Aequians
div2.p: a warlike mountain tribe on the upper Anio, warring against Rome (till 304), 1.35.

div2.head: Claudius Aesopus
div2.p: an intimate friend of Cicero, Rome's greatest tragic actor, 1.114.

div2.head: Africa
div2.p: the province in which Carthage was, 1.112 (Thapsus); 3.99 (Carthage).

div2.head: Agamemnon
div2.p: leader of the war against Troy; when detained at Aulis he sacrificed his daughter Iphigenia to save the expedition, 3.95.
For this he was slain on his return from Troy by his wife Clytaemnestra.

div2.head: Agesilaus
div2.p: king of Sparta (398-360); waged war in Asia (396-394), victor at Coronea, saviour of Sparta after Mantinea (362); 2.16.

div2.head: Agis IV
div2.p: king of Sparta (244-240); attempted to re-establish the institutions of Lycurgus and reform property abuses; put to death through organized wealth 2.80.

div2.head: Agrarian Laws
div2.p: a menace to the stability of the government, 2.78–83.

div2.head: Agrigentum
div2.p: a city on the south coast of Sicily, once the most beautiful city of mortals, ruled by Phalaris (560), 2.26.

div2.head: Ajax
div2.p: son of Telamon; could brook no wrong, went mad, and committed suicide when the arms of Achilles were awarded to Odysseus, 1.113.
Subject of a tragedy by Ennius, 1.114.

div2.head: Titus Albucius
div2.p: an Epicurean; praetor in Sardinia (105); prosecuted for extortion, 2.50.

div2.head: Alexander
div2.p: the Great (356-323), son of Philip of Macedon, 2.16, 48.
greater than his father in achievement, inferior in courtliness, 1.90.
conquered Greece (338-335), subdued Asia (334-331), Egypt (331), invaded India (329-327), founded Alexandria and other cities, and died of a drunken debauch (I, 90).

div2.head: Alexander
div2.p: tyrant of Pherae (369); brother, son-in-law, and successor of Jason (q.v.), defeated and slew Pelopidas of Thebes at Cynoscephalae (364); murdered by his wife and her three brothers, 2.25, 26.

div2.head: Alexandria
div2.p: the metropolis of Egypt at the mouth of the Nile; founded by Alexander (332); centre of wealth (II, 82); grain market, 3.50.

div2.head: Alps
div2.p: the mountains between Italy and further Gaul, 2.28.

div2.head: Anio
div2.p: the Sabine river, tributary to the Tiber; the battle on (340), which gave Rome supremacy over all Latium, 3.112.

div2.head: Anniceris
div2.p: of Cyrene (4th century), a successor of Aristippus; his school a cross between the Epicurean and the Cyrenaic: he denied that pleasure was merely absence of pain; he held that every act had its own distinct purpose and that the virtues are good in themselves; his teachings were not permanent, 3.116.

div2.head: Antigonus
div2.p: one of Alexander's generals, governor of Asia (323-301), king of Asia (306-301); father of Demetrius Poliorcetes and Philip, 2.48.

div2.head: Antiope
div2.p: mother of Amphion and Zethus, by whom she was saved from the persecutions of her former husband Lycus and his wife Dirce; her vengeance on Dirce drove her mad; subject of a tragedy of Pacuvius, 1.114.

div2.head: Antipater
div2.p: vice-regent of Macedon (334); father of Cassander, 2.48.
Antipater, of Tarsus (2nd century), pupil and successor of Diogenes of Babylonia; teacher of Panaetius; his ethical teachings, 3.51–55, 91.

div2.head: Antipater
div2.p: of Tyre (1st century), friend of Cato the younger; a Stoic, 2.86.

div2.head: Marcus Antonius
div2.p: father of Cicero's colleague and grandfather of the triumvir.

div2.head: Apelles
div2.p: of Cos (4th century), the greatest painter of his age; court painter to Alexander the Great; is masterpiece was a Venus rising from the sea; another Venus left unfinished, 3.10.

div2.head: Apollo
div2.p: god of the light of day; giver of oracles at Pytho, 2.77.

div2.head: Gaius Aquilius Gallus
div2.p: famous jurist; Cicero's colleague in the praetorship; author of formulae on criminal fraud, 3.60–61.

div2.head: Manius Aquilius
div2.p: consul (101) with Marius; victorious in the Servile War in Sicily; prosecuted (98) but acquitted, 2.50.

div2.head: Aratus
div2.p:
of Sicyon, soldier and statesman (271-213), removed the tyrant Nicoles (251) and averted
financial ruin, 2.81, 82.
leader of the Achaean League; poisoned by order of Philip of Macedon.

div2.head: Areopagites
div2.p: members of the Council of Areopagus.

div2.head: Areopagus
div2.p: Mars Hill, a spur of the Acropolis, seat of the highest court of Athens; the court itself, with powers of senate and supreme court, reorganized and enlarged in function by Solon, 1.75.

div2.head: Arginusae
div2.p: a group of islands off the coast of Asia Minor, near Lesbos, scene of the victory of the Athenian fleet (406), 1.84.

div2.head: Aristides
div2.p: fought at Marathon (490), Salamis (480), and commanded the Athenians at Plataea (479); exiled (483) because his policies clashed with those of Themistocles.

div2.head: Aristippus
div2.p: of Cyrene (flourished 370), founder of the Cyrenaic school, 3.116.

disciple of Socrates, but taught that the chief end of man was to get enjoyment from everything (hedonism), to subject all things and circumstances to himself for pleasure; but pleasure must be the slave not the master; good and bad identical with pleasure and pain; 1.148.

div2.head: Aristo
div2.p: of Chios (3rd century), a Stoic philosopher, pupil of Zeno; he taught indifference to externals, nothing good but virtue, nothing evil but vice; his theories rejected, 1.6.

div2.head: Aristotle
div2.p: (385-322), disciple of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great; founder of the Peripatetic school; greatest of philosophers, master of all knowledge—physics, metaphysics, natural philosophy, ethics, politics, poetics, sociology, logic, rhetoric, etc.; 2.56; 3.35.
might have been a great orator, 1.4.

div2.head: Arpinates
div2.p: the people of Arpinum owners of public lands, 1.21.

div2.head: Arpinum
div2.p: a town in Latium, birth place of Cicero and Gaius Marius, 1.21.

div2.head: Athenians
div2.p: left their homes to fight at Salamis, 3.48.

div2.head: Athens
div2.p: the intellectual and artistic centre of the world; led Greece in the Persian wars (490-479); humbled by Sparta (404); the university city of the Roman world, 1.1; 3.6, 121.

div2.head: Atreus
div2.p: son of Pelops and father of Agamemnon and Menelaus, murderer of his half-brother Chrysippus and of his brother Thyestes's children; murdered by his nephew Aegisthus; a fruitful theme for tragedy, 1.97; 3.106.

div2.head: Attic
div2.p: belonging to Attica, the province in which Athens is situated; Attic comedy, the comedy of Aristophanes, Eupolis, Menander, etc., 1.104.

div2.head: Avarice
div2.p: due to delusion as to expediency, 3.36.
contrary to all law, 3.21–23; see also Covetousness.

div2.head: Babylonia
div2.p: the district around Babylon at the head of the Persian Gulf, 3.51.

div2.head: Bardulis
div2.p: king of Illyria, conquered a large part of Macedonia from Perdiccas, the brother and predecessor of Philip; defeated and slain by Philip (358); called a brigand, because his career did not tend to promote civilization, 2.40.

div2.head: Lucius Basilus
div2.p: Minucius, otherwise unknown; perhaps Sulla's lieutenant, 3.73–74.

div2.head: Lucius Brutus
div2.p:
Junius, led the
Romans to expel the Tarquins; helped by Collatinus, who shared with him the first consulship (509), 3.40.

div2.head: Marcus Brutus
div2.p: Junius, an eminent jurist, one of the three founders of the civil law; father of the Accuser, 2.50.

div2.head: Marcus Junius Brutus Accusator
div2.p: orator and vigorous prosecutor, son of the preceding, 2.50.

div2.head: Gaius Caesar
div2.p: Julius, son of Lucius Caesar Strabo Vopiscus, candidate for the consulship (88), slain by Marius (87); poet and orator, 1.108, 133.

div2.head: Gaius Caesar
div2.p: Julius (100-44), consul (59), in Gaul (58-50), conquered Pompey at Pharsalus (48), dictator (48-44), assassinated (44); orator, statesman, scholar, soldier; despot, 2.2.
a conspirator with Catiline, his love of wrong, 2.84.

div2.head: Callicratidas
div2.p: succeeded Lysander as admiral of the Spartan fleet, 1.109.
defeated Conon, took Lesbos, lost the battle and his life at Arginusae (406), 1.84.

div2.head: Calliphon
div2.p: a Greek philosopher, probably a disciple of Epicurus, taught that the supreme good was a union between moral rectitude and pleasure, 3.119.
Lucius Calpurnius Piso Frugi; see Piso.

div2.head: Calypso
div2.p: the nymph of Ogygia, who kept Odysseus (Ulysses) with her seven years, 1.113.

div2.head: Campus
div2.p: (Martius), the open plain next to the Tiber outside the north wall of Rome; playground and drillground, 1.104.

div2.head: Cannae
div2.p: a town on the Aufidus in Apulia, scene of Hannibal's overwhelming defeat of the Romans (216), 1.40; 3.47, 113.

div2.head: Capitolium
div2.p: the Capitoline Hill, between the forum and the Tiber, the citadel of Rome, with the temple of Jupiter and Good Faith, 3.104.

div2.head: Carthage
div2.p: once a mighty city, on the north central coast of Africa, 3.99, 100.
the most formidable commercial and military rival of Rome; conquered by Rome in the First Punic War (264-241), 1.39.

div2.head: Cassander
div2.p: son of Antipater, disinherited by his father, gained the throne of Macedonia (306) by wars and murders (319-301), 2.48.

div2.head: Marcus Cato
div2.p: Porcius, the Censor (or Major, the Elder, I, 37) (234-149), author, 1.104; 3.1.
soldier, served in Second Punic War (217-202); statesman, responsible for the destruction of Carthage (146), 1.79; the Wise, 3.16.
consul (195); censor (184); stalwart champion of the simple life and stern morals, 2.89.
bitterly opposed luxury and Greek culture; yielded in old age.

div2.head: Marcus Cato
div2.p: Porcius, son of the preceding; jurist; served under Paulus in Macedon (168), 1.37; [under Marcus Popilius Laenas in Liguria (172), 1.36].

div2.head: Marcus Cato
div2.p: Porcius, grandson of the Censor and father of Cato Uticensis, 3.66.

div2.head: Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis
div2.p:
(95-46), son of the preceding and great-grandson of the Cen-
sor; a Stoic philosopher; orator; soldier, 1.112.
stern and unyielding as his great-grandfather, 1.112; 3.88.

div2.head: Quintus Catulus
div2.p: Lutatius, half-brother of Julius Caesar Strabo, 1.133.
author; soldier; consul with Marius (102) in the war against the Cimbri (101); gentleman, 1.109.
committed suicide to escape the proscriptions of Marius (87).

div2.head: Quintus Catulus
div2.p: Lutatius, son of the preceding, defeated Lepidus at the Milvian bridge; statesman, 1.76.

div2.head: Caudium
div2.p: a little town in the mountains of Samnium; near it are the Caudine Forks, the scene of the disastrous battle (321); 3.109; (II, 79).

div2.head: Celtiberians
div2.p: a powerful people of central Spain, opposed Rome in Second Punic War, were reduced in the Numantian War (134), submitted on the death of Sertorius (72), 1.38.

div2.head: Chremes
div2.p: a character in Terence's Heauton Timorumenus, 1.30.

div2.head: Chrysippus
div2.p: of Soli (250-207), studied Stoic philosophy at Athens under Cleanthes, whom he succeeded; voluminous writer. Had there been no Chrysippus, there had been no Stoa, 3.42.

div2.head: Marcus Cicero
div2.p: Tullius, the orator (106-43), born at Arpinum, educated at Rome under Archias, the Scaevolas, and the teachers of philosophy (see Introduction), at Athens, in Asia, and at Rhodes; his training was all for service, 1.155.
as consul (63) he crushed the conspiracy of Catiline, 1.84.
his enforced retirement from his profession, 3.2–4.
attitude on the downfall of the republic, 2.2.

div2.head: Marcus Cicero
div2.p: and Sextus Pompey; a student of Peripatetic philosophy under Cratippus in Athens (44-43), 1.1.
admonished to read also his father's works, 1.3; 3.121.
served under Brutus (43-42); consul with Octavian (30).

div2.head: Cimbrians
div2.p: a Celtic people, migrating in a vast horde toward Italy, were cut to pieces by Marius and Catulus in the Raudian Plains near Verona (101), 1.38.

div2.head: Cimon
div2.p: of Athens, son of the great Miltiades; victorious admiral; statesman; genial and generous, 2.64.

div2.head: Circe
div2.p: nymph of Aeaea, a sorceress; she kept Odysseus (Ulysses) in her halls a year, 1.113.

div2.head: Civic
div2.p: see Appius and Centumalus and Pulcher.

div2.head: Cleombrotus
div2.p: son of Pausanias, king of Sparta, fell at Leuctra (371), 1.84.

div2.head: Publius Clodius Pulcher
div2.p: Cicero's inveterate enemy, one of the most turbulent and corrupt characters of Rome, guilty of mutiny in the army, bribery in the courts, profligacy in his public and private life.; secured Cicero's banishment; hired gladiators to force his own election to the praetorship, but was killed in a broil with Milo's rival gang of ruffians, 2.58.

div2.head: Cloelia
div2.p: a Roman girl sent as a hostage to Porsena; she made her escape by swimming the Tiber, was sent back, but restored by the king with rewards for her courage, 1.61.

div2.head: Clytaemnestra
div2.p:
daughter of Tyndareus, wife of Agamemnon,
paramour of Aegisthus, with whom she murdered her husband on his return from Troy; she was in turn slain by her son Orestes. Subject of a tragedy by Accius, 1.114.

div2.head: Horatius Codes
div2.p: the hero who with two others kept the bridge against Porsena and Tarquin, 1.61.

div2.head: Lucius Collatinus
div2.p: Tarquinius, husband of Lucretia, associate of Brutus in driving out the Tarquins and his colleague in the first consulship (509), 3.40.

div2.head: Conon
div2.p: famous Athenian admiral, defeated by Lysander at Aegospotami (405), victorious over Pisander of Sparta at Cnidus (394), restored the long walls, 1.116.

div2.head: Considerateness
div2.p: a subdivision of the virtue of Temperance, 1.99, 143.

div2.head: Corinth
div2.p: a famous city at the Isthmus of Corinth; wealthy; next to Athens, richest in treasures of art; head of the Achaean League; sacked and utterly destroyed by the Romans under Mummius (146), 1.35; 2.76; 3.46.
see Scipio and Spinther and Sulla.

div2.head: Cos
div2.p: chief city of the island of Cos, one of the Sporades; famed for its silks; the birthplace of Apelles, painter of the Coan Venus, 3.10.

div2.head: Gaius Cotta
div2.p: Aurelius, distinguished orator; one of the speakers in Cicero's de Oratore and de Natura Deorum; consul (75); 2.59.

div2.head: Lucius Crassus
div2.p: at 21 (119) he won renown by his prosecution of Carbo, the one-time friend of the Gracchi, 2.47, 49.
as consul (95), he secured the expulsion from Rome of all who were not citizens, 3.47.
this was a cause of the Social War. He was the greatest orator of Rome before Cicero, fluent, graceful, witty, 1.108, 133.
Cicero's mouthpiece in the de Oratore.

div2.head: Marcus Licinius Crassus Dives
div2.p: the triumvir; his wealth and ambition, 1.25.
sided with Sulla against Marius and grew enormously rich by the proscriptions; his avarice did not shrink from any meanness or even crime, 1.109; 3.73–75.
He defeated Spartacus (71); slain in Parthia (53).

div2.head: Publius Licinius Crassus Dives
div2.p: father of the triumvir, consul (97); ended his own life to escape the proscriptions of Marius (87); Cicero bought his house.

div2.head: Cratippus
div2.p: of Mitylene, an eminent Peripatetic, came to Athens (about 50) to lecture; foremost of contemporary philosophers and teacher of young Cicero, 1.1, 2; 2.8; 3.5, 6, 33, 121.

div2.head: Cynics
div2.p: a school of philosophy so called from the Athenian gymnasium, Cynosarges, where they met, later adapted to their snarling manner and dirty habits; its leaders were Antisthenes of Athens, a disciple of Socrates, and Diogenes of Sinope; they taught the virtue of poverty and want, indifference to all convention and decency; Cicero's contempt for them and their so-called philosophy, 1.128, 148.

div2.head: Cyrenaics
div2.p: the philosophic sect founded by Aristippus (q.v.), 3.116.

div2.head: Cyrus
div2.p:
the Great, founder of the
Persian Empire; wonderfully gifted in winning the co-operation of men and nations, 2.16.

div2.head: Damon
div2.p: a Pythagorean and friend of Phintias, 3.45.

div2.head: Publius Decius Mus
div2.p: the former, consul with Manlius Torquatus (360), devoted himself to death in the battle on the Veseris. The son did the same at the battle of Sentinum (295) and brought the Samnite wars to an end.

div2.head: Demetrius of Phalerum
div2.p: the only Greek who was both orator and philosopher, 1.3.
he inspired the founding of the Alexandrine library.

div2.head: Demetrius Poliorcetes
div2.p: son of Antigonus and king of Macedon (294-287). His life was occupied with continuous warfare against enemies in Egypt, Asia, Greece, Macedonia, Epirus.

div2.head: Demosthenes
div2.p: the greatest orator of Athens (385-322); pupil of Isaeus and of Plato, 1.4.
might have been a great philosopher, 1.4.
he prosecuted his defaulting guardian with success, 2.47.
then turned to public speaking and statecraft as a profession.

div2.head: Diana
div2.p: goddess of the light of the night, identified with Artemis, 3.95.

div2.head: Dicaearchus
div2.p: of Messana (4th century), a Peripatetic philosopher, geographer, and historian, 2.16.
pupil of Aristotle and friend of Theophrastus.

div2.head: Dinomachus
div2.p: a Greek philosopher, always named with Calliphon (q.v.), 3.119.

div2.head: Diogenes
div2.p: of Babylonia, pupil and successor of Chrysippus; best known for his part in the famous embassy with Carneades and Critolaus from Athens to Rome (156), where, on motion of Cato, they were not permitted to remain; his ethics rather loose, 3.51–55, 91.

div2.head: Dion
div2.p: a kinsman of the elder Dionysius and tyrant of Syracuse (356-353); a devoted disciple of Plato at Syracuse and Athens, 1.155.

div2.head: Dionysius
div2.p: the elder (430-367), tyrant of Syracuse (405-367), a typically cruel tyrant, suspicious and fearful, 2.25; 3.45 (?); devoted to art and literature, himself a poet crowned with a prize at Athens.

div2.head: Dionysius
div2.p: the younger, son of the preceding and tyrant of Syracuse (367–356, 346-343); devoted to literature; Plato, Aristippus, Archytas, and others were brought to his court. Whether the Damon and Phintias story is to be connected with him or his father is uncertain, 3.45 (?).

div2.head: Marcus Drusus
div2.p: Livius, son of Gaius Gracchus's colleague in the tribuneship; an eloquent orator, 1.108.
as tribune (91) he attempted to renew the social and agrarian legislation of Gracchus and was assassinated.

div2.head: Duty
div2.p: the most important subject in philosophy, 1.4.
to those who have wronged us, 1.33.
of aliens, 1.125; vs. claims of friendship, 3.43–44.
change of duty in change of circumstance, 1.31, 59; 3.32; mean and absolute duty, 1.8; 3.14.

div2.head: Quintus Ennius
div2.p: (239-169), a Greek by birth, the father of Roman poetry, wrote an epic (the Annals), 1.84.

div2.head: Epaminondas
div2.p: one of the greatest men of Greece, a student of Pythagorean philosophy, 1.155.
the greatest general of Thebes, victorious at Leuctra (371), 1.84.
humbled Sparta and made Thebes the leading city of Greece; fell at Mantinea (362).

div2.head: Epicurus
div2.p: (342-270), founded at Athens the school that bears his name; author of 300 books, natural and ethical philosophy; held happiness to be the highest good; Cicero confuses his teaching here with that of Aristippus and the Cyrenaics; with the latter, happiness consists in individual pleasures; with Epicurus, it is permanent calm of soul and freedom from pain, with pure and lasting pleasures——the pleasures that come from a life of righteousness, 3.12, 117.
the gods existed but had nothing to do with human life, 3.102.
adopted the atomic theory. His own life was temperate even to abstinence; his followers went to excess. A very popular school, 3.116.

div2.head: Epigoni
div2.p: the sons of the Seven against Thebes; under Alcmaeon, Diomedes, etc., they conquered and destroyed the city. Subject of a tragedy of Accius, 1.114.

div2.head: Erillus
div2.p: of Carthage, pupil of Zeno the Stoic, held that knowledge is the only good, while everything else is neither good nor evil; his ethical theories rejected, 1.6.

div2.head: Eteocles
div2.p: son of Oedipus, drove out his brother Polynices, in order to reign alone, and brought on the war of the Seven against Thebes; the brothers fell by each other's hands, 3.82.

div2.head: Euripides
div2.p: (480-406), tragic poet of Athens; disciple of Anaxagoras and friend of Socrates; wrote 75 to 90 plays; 17 are extant; Cicero quotes from the Hippolytus, 3.82.

div2.head: Gaius Fabricius Luscinus
div2.p: hero of old Rome, famed for integrity and moral dignity; called the Just, 3.16, 87.
consul (282); served against Pyrrhus (280); ambassador to Pyrrhus to negotiate exchange of prisoners; Pyrrhus tried to gain his favour by appeals to his ambition, avarice, and fears—in vain, 1.38.
consul again (278), he sent back to Pyrrhus the traitor, 1.40; 3.86–87.
a rigorous censor (275); lived and died in poverty.

div2.head: Fear
div2.p: dangerous to the one who employs it, 2.26.

div2.head: Fetial Law
div2.p: the laws of the Fetiales, a college of four priests who served as guardians of the public faith; they conducted the ceremonies attendant upon demands for redress, declarations of war, ratification of treaties, establishment of peace; 1.36; 3.108.

div2.head: Gaius Fimbria
div2.p: Flavius, colleague of Marius in his second consulship (104); orator and jurist, 3.77.

div2.head: Lucius Fufius
div2.p: an orator of no great ability, 2.50.

div2.head: Lucius Furius Philus
div2.p: a learned interlocutor in Cicero's Republic.

div2.head: Gaul
div2.p: an inhabitant of Gaul, the land north of the Apennines, 3.112.

div2.head: Generosity
div2.p: must not harm its object, 1.42–43: in proportion to one's means, 1.42–44; 2.55.

div2.head: Gaius Gracchus
div2.p: Sempronius, brother of the younger Tiberius; a more radical reformer; tribune (123 and 122); fell (121) a martyr to his reforms for the restoration of the public lands and the reduction of the cost of living, 2.72, 80.

div2.head: Publius Gracchus
div2.p: Sempronius, father of the elder Tiberius, 2.43.

div2.head: Tiberius Gracchus
div2.p: in his own tribuneship he defended Scipio (187); a great soldier, 2.80.
twice consul, triumphed twice; a just ruler in Spain; son-in-law of the elder, father-in-law of the younger Africanus, an ardent aristocrat; hence Cicero's praise, 2.43.

div2.head: Tiberius Gracchus
div2.p: Sempronius, son of the foregoing; a persuasive orator; friend of the people and helper of the poor and oppressed; murdered for attempting as tribune (133) to reform agrarian abuses and build up a class of small farmers, 1.76, 109; 2.80.

div2.head: Greece
div2.p: the land of liberty, letters, art, and civilization, 2.60; 3.48, 73, 99.

div2.head: Greek
div2.p: belonging to or a native of Greece, 1.108, 111; 2.83; 3.82.

div2.head: Gyges
div2.p: the shepherd who dethroned Candaules and became king of Lydia (716-678), 3.38, 78.

div2.head: Gytheum
div2.p: the harbour-town and arsenal of Sparta, 3.49.

div2.head: Hamilcar
div2.p: a successful Carthaginian general in the First Punic War, defeated by Regulus at Ecnomus; opposed Regulus in Africa, 3.99.

div2.head: Hamilcar Barca
div2.p: famous commander of the Carthaginian forces in Sicily (247-241); in Spain (238-229); father of Hannibal, 3.99.

div2.head: Hannibal
div2.p: (247-183), one of the world's greatest generals, 1.108.
sacked Saguntum (219), crossed the Alps and defeated the Romans on the Trebia and Ticinus (218), at Trasimenus (217), Cannae (216), 1.40; 3.113–114.
defeated at Zama (202); maligned by the Romans as treacherous and cruel, 1.38.

div2.head: Hecaton
div2.p: of Rhodes, a Stoic, pupil of Panaetius, 3.63, 89.

div2.head: Hercules
div2.p: the greatest of heroes, son of Zeus (Jupiter) and Alcmena, 1.118.
his choice of his path in life, 1.118.
performer of the twelve labours; benefactor of humanity, 3.25.

div2.head: Hernicians
div2.p: a tribe in the Sabine mountains, subdued by Rome (306), 1.35.

div2.head: Herodotus
div2.p: of Halicarnassus (5th century), lived also at Athens and Thurii; the father of history; travelled widely and wrote the history of Persia and Greece, 2.41.

div2.head: Hesiod
div2.p: the Boeotian didactic poet (8th century); author of the Theogony, the Works and Days, etc., 1.48.

div2.head: Hippolytus
div2.p: son of Theseus; his step-mother Phaedra fell in love with him; he rejected her advances but promised not to tell, 3.108.
she accused him falsely; his innocence proved, Phaedra hanged herself and Theseus suffered life-long remorse, 1.32; 3.94.

div2.head: Home
div2.p: of man of rank; see House.

div2.head: Homer
div2.p: the poet, author of Iliad and Odyssey, 3.97.

div2.head: House
div2.p: suitable for a man of rank, 1.138–140.

div2.head: Quintus Hortensius
div2.p: (114-50), Cicero's famous rival as orator and advocate; his close friend (after 63), 3.73.
enormously wealthy; lavish in his aedileship (75), 2.57.

div2.head: Illyria
div2.p: the country between Macedonia and the Adriatic, 2.40.

div2.head: Iphigenia
div2.p: daughter of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra (q.v.); sacrificed at Aulis, 3.95.

div2.head: Isocrates
div2.p: (436-338), one of the ten Attic orators, pupil of Gorgias and Socrates; a polished speaker; greater as a teacher than as an orator; might have been a great philosopher, 1.4.

div2.head: Italian War
div2.p: (90-88), caused by Rome's injustice to the allies, provoked by the fear of prosecution on the part of the corrupt aristocrats, 2.75.
resulted in Rome's granting the contentions of the allies.

div2.head: Ithaca
div2.p: the home of Odysseus (Ulysses), an island of the Ionian group west of Greece, probably the historical Leucas, 3.97.

div2.head: Janus
div2.p: an old Italian sungod; a covered passage (commonly called his temple) adjoining the forum accommodated the banking houses of Rome, 2.87.

div2.head: Jason
div2.p: tyrant of Pherae (395-370), generalissimo of Thessaly (374-370), an able soldier and diplomat, 1.108.

div2.head: Jugurtha
div2.p: king of Numidia (118-106), campaigned with Scipio against Numantia; war with Rome (112-106) protracted by his bribes as much as by his arms, 3.79.
see Brutus and Pennus and Silanus.

div2.head: Jupiter
div2.p: the greatest of the gods of Italy, 3.102, 105; Supreme and Best, 3.104.

div2.head: Quintus Labeo
div2.p: Fabius, grandson of Fabius Maximus, consul (183); injustice of, 1.33.

div2.head: Laciads
div2.p: citizens of the deme of Lacia, west of Athens, the home of Miltiades, 2.64.

div2.head: Gaius Laelius
div2.p: statesman; soldier under Scipio at Carthage, successful against Viriathus, 2.40.
a Stoic, pupil of Diogenes and Panaetius; a man of endless charm and wit, 1.90, 108.
a man of letters, centre of the literary group comprising also Scipio, Panaetius, Polybius, Terence, Lucilius.

div2.head: Latins
div2.p: the people of Latium, the province in which Rome is situated, the first territory added to Rome, 1.38.

div2.head: Law
div2.p: its decline with the end of the republic, 2.67; 3.2.

div2.head: Publius Cornelius Lentulus Spinther
div2.p: as consul (57) he was largely instrumental in securing Cicero's recall from banishment.

div2.head: Leuctra
div2.p: a town of Boeotia, where the Spartans under Cleombrotus were disastrously defeated by Epaminondas and the Thebans (371), 1.61; 2.26.

div2.head: Lucius Lucullus
div2.p: Licinius (110-56), surnamed Ponticus for his victories over Mithradates (84-66); famed for his wealth and magnificence, 1.140.
for the splendour of his aedileship with his brother Marcus (79), 2.57.
with him prosecuted Servilius to avenge their father whom he had accused of bribery and corruption, 2.50.
patron of letters, especially of the poet Archias.

div2.head: Marcus Lucullus
div2.p: Licinius, associated with his brother Lucius (q.v.), 2.50, 57.

div2.head: Lycurgus
div2.p: (9th century), the famous lawgiver of Sparta, author (?) of the Spartan constitution, 1.76.

div2.head: Lydia
div2.p: the central country of western Asia Minor, 3.38.

div2.head: Lysander
div2.p: the Spartan admiral who defeated the Athenians at Aegospotami (405), received the capitulation of Athens (404), established the Thirty Tyrants (403), and gave Sparta her leadership, 1.76, 109.

div2.head: Lysander
div2.p:
the ephor (241), a descendant of the admiral, a friend of King Agis (q.v.), sought to bring
about agrarian reforms based upon the constitution of Lycurgus; for this he was banished, 2.80.

div2.head: Lysis
div2.p: of Tarentum, a Pythagorean; expelled from Italy, he came to Thebes and taught Epaminondas, 1.155.

div2.head: Macedonia
div2.p: until the time of Philip a small country north of Thessaly, 1.37.

div2.head: Quintus Maelius
div2.p: tribune (321), more probably tribune-elect, as tribunes could not leave the city, 3.109.

div2.head: Aemilius Lepidus Mamercus Livianus
div2.p: a kinsman of Caesar; though defeated once, 2.58.

div2.head: Gaius Mancinus
div2.p: Hostilius; in his consulship (137) he was defeated by the Numantines; his delivery to the enemy, 2.109.

div2.head: Lucius Manlius Capitolinus Imperiosus
div2.p: named dictator to mark the year (363), he used his office to engage in a war; that he transgressed but a few days was due to the intervention of the tribunes, 3.112.

div2.head: Titus Manlius Imperiosus Torquatus
div2.p: his son, a famous hero of Roman story; as consul at the time of the battle on the Veseris he executed his own son for disobeying orders, though the disobedience won the spolia opima, 3.112.

div2.head: Marathon
div2.p: a plain about twenty miles north of Athens where (490) Miltiades and his ten thousand defeated the hosts of Darius, 1.61.

div2.head: Marcus Marcellus
div2.p: Claudius, campaigned against Hannibal in Italy, took Syracuse (212), five times consul, a brave but cruel soldier, over-praised by the Romans, 1.61.

div2.head: Gaius Marius
div2.p: (157-87), seven times consul; gained his first consulship dishonourably, 3.79, 81.
conquered Jugurtha (107); saved Rome from the invading Cimbri (102) and Teutons (101); a military genius, 1.76.
cruel and selfish, he flooded the streets of Rome with her best blood in the civil war with Sulla.

div2.head: Marcus Marius Gratidianus
div2.p: the son (or grandson) of Marcus Gratidius whose sister married Cicero's grandfather; adopted by a kinsman of the great Marius; hence his name; twice praetor; murdered by Catiline during Sulla's proscriptions, 3.67.
his unbounded popularity in his first praetorship (86), 3.80–81.

div2.head: Marseilles
div2.p: (Massilia), a Greek city on the southern coast of Gaul, independent of the province; it sided with Pompey; Caesar captured the city after a protracted siege and exacted cruel vengeance, 2.28.

div2.head: Quintus Fabius Maximus Cunctator
div2.p: consul four times; in his second dictatorship (217) he won his surname by harassing Hannibal, watching his plans and working on the defensive, 1.84, 108.

div2.head: Medes
div2.p: the people of Media, a great kingdom in central Asia Minor added to Persia by Cyrus, 2.41.

div2.head: Medus
div2.p: a son of Media and Aegeus; wandering in search of his mother he came to Colchis, where Medea saved his life; the subject of a tragedy of Pacuvius, 1.114.

div2.head: Melanippa
div2.p: mother of Boeotus and Aeolus by Posidon (Neptune); blinded and imprisoned by her father, she was at last rescued by her sons and her sight was restored by Posidon; subject of a tragedy of Ennius, 1.114.

Quintus Caecilius Metellus
Macedonicus, won his surname by his victories over Andriscus (148); a political rival and yet a good friend of the younger Scipio, 1.87.

div2.head: Quintus Caecilius Metellus Numidicus
div2.p: nephew of the preceding, statesman and soldier; as consul (109), carried on the war with Jugurtha with distinguished success, 2.79.

div2.head: Metrodorus
div2.p: of Lampsacus (330-277), the most distinguished of the disciples of Epicurus; his Epicureanism was of the grossly sensual sort; his conception of happiness misunderstood by Cicero, 3.117.

div2.head: Titus Milo
div2.p: Annius, an unscrupulous and turbulent fellow; as tribune (57) he did much for Cicero's recall and made a sworn enemy of Clodius (q.v.); hired gladiators to force his own election, 2.58.
defended without success by Cicero for killing Clodius.

div2.head: Minos
div2.p: son of Zeus (Jupiter) and king of Crete; because of his upright life he was made judge with Aeacus (q.v.) in Hades, 1.97.

div2.head: Lucius Mummius Achaicus
div2.p: as consul (146) broke up the Achaean League, razed Corinth to the ground, 1.35; 2.46.
carried to Italy untold treasures of wealth and art, 2.76.

div2.head: Naples
div2.p: the beautiful Greek city of Campania, 1.33.

div2.head: Nola
div2.p: a city in Campania, loyal to Rome, 1.33.

div2.head: Numantia
div2.p: the capital of Celtiberia, razed to the ground after a long siege by the younger Scipio, 1.35, 76.

div2.head: Gnaeus Octavius
div2.p: as praetor commanded the fleet against Perseus (168) and gained a triumph; consul (165), 1.138.

div2.head: Marcus Octavius
div2.p: tribune (120); had the corn law of Gaius Gracchus repealed and secured the passage of a new and more conservative one, 2.72.

div2.head: Old Comedy
div2.p: that of Arietophanes, Cratinus, Eupolis, etc., the comedy of personal abuse, 1.104.

div2.head: Palamedes
div2.p: treacherously done to death in revenge.

div2.head: Palatine
div2.p: the hill above the forum on the south; east of the Capitol, 1.138.

div2.head: Panaetius
div2.p: of Rhodes (180-111 ca.), Stoic philosopher, disciple of Diogenes and Antipater (q.v.) at Athens, close friend of Laelius (q.v.) and Scipio, 1.90; 2.76.
wrote a book on moral duty, 3.7.
how it would have been met, 3.33.

defends lawyers'
efforts in a bad case, 2.51.

div2.head: Gaius Papius
div2.p: as tribune (65), revived the law of Pennus (q.v.), 3.47.

div2.head: Patriotism
div2.p: right to do wrong for one's country, 1.159.

div2.head: Lucius Paulus
div2.p: Aemilius, consul (216), defeated and slain at Cannae, 1.114.

div2.head: Lucius Aemilius Paulus Macedonicus
div2.p: son of the preceding; in his second consulship he conquered Perseus of Macedon at Pydna (168) and enriched Rome with spoils, 2.76.
the father of the younger Africanus, 1.116, 121.

div2.head: Pausanias
div2.p: king of Sparta, commander-in-chief of the forces of Greece at Plataea (479) to the glory of Sparta, 1.76.

div2.head: Peloponnesian War
div2.p: the death-struggle of Athens with Sparta (431-404), 1.84.

div2.head: Peloponnesus
div2.p: the lower peninsula of Greece, in which Sparta was the chief city, 1.84.

div2.head: Pelops
div2.p: son of Tantalus and king of Mycenae, father of Atreus and Thyestes, 3.84.

div2.head: Marcus Pennus
div2.p: Junius; as tribune (126) he secured a law expelling all foreigners from Rome, 3.47.

div2.head: Pericles
div2.p: philosopher, friend of Anaxagoras and Socrates; orator of mighty power, serious and deep, 1.108.
his administration made Athens unequalled in the splendour of her public buildings, 2.60.

div2.head: Peripatetics
div2.p: students of exact science; lack of poetry and eloquence of Plato but not very different from the New Academy, 1.2; 3.20.

div2.head: Perseus
div2.p: the last king of Macedon, conquered by Paulus (q.v.), 1.37.

div2.head: Persians
div2.p: the people of Persia, the great empire of western Asia; under Darius they invaded Greece and were beaten back at Marathon (490), 1.61.
under Xerxes were overwhelmingly defeated at Salamis (480), 1.61; 3.48, 49.

div2.head: Phaedra
div2.p: daughter of Minos, wife of Theseus and stepmother of Hippolytus (q.v.), 3.94.

div2.head: Phalaris
div2.p: tyrant of Agrigentum (6th century), type of inhuman cruelty, 2.26; 3.29, 32.
slain in an uprising of his people, II 26.

div2.head: Phalerum
div2.p: a deme of Attica on the bay of Phalerum, 1.3; 2.60.

div2.head: Pherae
div2.p: a town of south-eastern Thessaly, the home of Admetus; of Jason, 1.108.

div2.head: Philip
div2.p: conqueror, king of Macedon (359-336), educated at Thebes, cultured, 1.90.
eloquent, tactful and firm in discipline, 2.53.

div2.head: Lucius Philippus
div2.p: Marcius, orator second only to Crassus and Antonius, 1.108.
dishonest policy toward the Asiatic states, 3.87.

div2.head: Quintus Philippus
div2.p: Marcius, father of preceding, consul (186 and 169), 2.59; 3.87.

div2.head: Philosophy
div2.p: fg.; why Cicero turned to it, 2.2–8; 3.1–6.

div2.head: Phoenissae
div2.p: the Phoenician Women, a tragedy of Euripides dealing with the war of the Seven against Thebes, 3.82.

div2.head: Picenum
div2.p: state of north-east Italy, on the Adriatic, 3.74.

div2.head: Piraeus
div2.p: the great, landlocked harbour of Athens, about five miles from the city, 3.46.

div2.head: Lucius Calpurnius Piso Frugi
div2.p: so surnamed for his integrity; author and statesman; tribune (149); law against extortion, 2.75.

div2.head: Plataea
div2.p: the heroic little city at the foot of Mount Cithaeron in Boeotia; alone with Athens at Marathon (490); the scene of the final defeat of the Persians in Hellas (479), 1.61.

div2.head: Plato
div2.p: (429-347), pupil and friend of Socrates, profound philosopher and brilliant author, 1.22, 63.
might have been a great orator, 1.4.
founder of the Academy (q.v.); a great teacher, 1.155.

div2.head: Titus Plautus
div2.p: Maccius (254-184), the greatest of Rome's comic poets; rich in wit, 1.104.

div2.head: Po
div2.p: the great river of Cisalpine Gaul, 3.88.

div2.head: Polybius
div2.p: of Megalopolis (204-122), president of the Achaean League, detained at Rome in the house of Aemilius Paulus; friend of Scipio Aemilianus and Laelius; author of a history of Rome, 3.113.

div2.head: Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus
div2.p: (106-48), warrior, 1.76; (2.20;) politician, the enemy of Caesar, the idol of Cicero, 2.2.
conquered the pirates, Sertorians, Mithradates, Judaea, 1.78.

div2.head: Quintus Pompeius Rufus
div2.p: consul (141); as commander in the war with Numantia (140) made the unfortunate peace, 3.109.

div2.head: Sextus Pompey
div2.p: cousin of Pompey the Great, Stoic, scholar, geometrician, 1.19.

div2.head: Gaius Pontius
div2.p: the Samnite general, victor at the Caudine Forks (321), 2.75.
faithlessly treated, defeated (292), and executed in Rome.

div2.head: Posidonius
div2.p: of Apamea (135-51), a Stoic, disciple of Panaetius at Athens, 3.8.
established a school at Rhodes where Cicero studied under him; later he lived with Cicero in Rome; author of many works, 1.159; 3.10.

div2.head: Spurius Postumius Albinus
div2.p: defeated in his second consulship (321) at the Caudine Forks, 3.109.

div2.head: Prodicus
div2.p: of Ceos (fifth century), a respected sophist; his Choice of Hercules, 1.118.

div2.head: Promises
div2.p: sacred though given to an enemy 1.39–40.

div2.head: Propriety
div2.p: its relations to the Cardinal Virtues, 1.93–100.
conduct in accord with personal endowment, 1.110–117.

div2.head: Propylaea
div2.p: the magnificent gateway to the Acropolis of Athens, built (437-431) by Pericles and Mnesicles at a cost of £500,000, 2.60.

div2.head: Philadelphus Ptolemy
div2.p: (309-247), king of Egypt, patron of art and letters, had the Bible translated; vastly rich, 2.82.

div2.head: Pyrrho
div2.p: of Elis (fourth century), founder of the school of the Sceptics; held that virtue is the only good, that truth and knowledge are unattainable; his ethical theories rejected, 1.6.

div2.head: Pyrrhus
div2.p: (318-272), king of Epirus, descended from Achilles and Aeacus, 1.38.
a daring soldier and a gallant enemy, 1.38.
a career of adventure and conquest, 1.38; 3.86.
invaded Italy (280-275); the story of the poisoner, 1.40; 3.86; (see also Fabricius); invaded Macedonia (273) and the enemy's troops joined him, 2.26.

div2.head: Pythagorean
div2.p: a follower of Pythagoras or member of his secret fraternity, 1.155; 3.45.

div2.head: Pythagoras
div2.p: of Samos (sixth century), studied in the Orient, great mathematician; moral and religious teacher; serious, ascetic, 1.108.
taught transmigration of souls; founded a secret brother-hood of ideal friendship, 1.56.
asceticism was the rile of practice, with deep meditation and lofty aspiration.

div2.head: Pythian
div2.p: epithet of Apollo, from Pytho, another name for Delphi, 2.77.

div2.head: Quirinus
div2.p: the Sabine name for the deified Romulus, 3.41.

div2.head: Marcus Regulus
div2.p: Atilius, a favourite hero of old Rome; consul (267 and 256), annihilated the Carthaginian fleet, took many towns, was finally (255) defeated and taken prisoner, 1.39; 3.99.
his famous embassy and the ethics of his conduct, 3.99–115.

div2.head: Remus
div2.p: twin brother of Romulus, slain for leaping in derision over the new walls of Rome, 3.41.

div2.head: Rhodes
div2.p: a large island off the coast of Caria, 3.50.

div2.head: Rome
div2.p: the capital of the Empire and mistress of the world, 1.39, 40; 3.73, 79, 99, 112, 113.

div2.head: Romulus
div2.p: the mythical king, founder of Rome, 3.40.
builder of its walls; not justified in slaying his brother, 3.41.

div2.head: Sextus Roscius
div2.p: of Ameria, accused by Chrysogonus, a freedman of Sulla's, of murdering his father; bravely and successfully defended by Cicero at the age of twenty-six, 2.51.

div2.head: Publius Rutilius Rufus
div2.p: with Quintus Scaevola in Asia he repressed the extortion of the publicans, was banished, and devoted his life to philosophy and literature, 3.10.

div2.head: Sabine
div2.p: belonging to the province of central Italy, 3.74.
the Sabines, unfriendly to Rome till subdued and added to the empire (290), 1.35, 38.
Sacred Laws; the Leges Sacralue. laws for the violation of which the offender was nominally consecrated to some god—i.e., laden with a curse, 3.111.

div2.head: Salamis
div2.p: the island and straits directly in front of the Piraeus (q.v.),where (480) Themistocles and the allied Greeks virtually annihilated the fleets of Persia, 1.61, 75.

div2.head: Sale
div2.p: fraud in sale of real estate, 3.54–64.

div2.head: Salmacis
div2.p: a fountain (and nymph) at Halicarnassus, whose waters made men who drank them weak and effeminate, 1.61.

div2.head: Samnites
div2.p: the brave, liberty-loving people of Samnium, a province of south-central Italy; after seventy-one years (343-272) of war with Rome admitted to citizenship, 1.38.
famous for their victory at the Caudine Forks, 3.109.

div2.head: Sardinia
div2.p: the large island north of Sicily, made a province (238), misgoverned, 2.50.

div2.head: Marcus Minucius Basilus Satrianus
div2.p: adopted by Lucius Minucius Basilus, his inheritance, 3.74.

div2.head: Publius Scaevola
div2.p: Mucius, father of the pontifex maximus consul (133) and friend of Tiberius Gracchus, an expert in the pontifical law, 2.47.

div2.head: Quintus Scaevola
div2.p: Mucius, the Augur, son of the preceding, son-in-law of Laelius, friend of Africanus, consul (117), preceptor to Cicero; simple in his greatness, 1.109.

div2.head: Quintus Scaevola
div2.p: Mucius, the Pontifex Maximus, son of Publius, preceptor of Cicero; orator, jurist; authority on the civil law, his business honour, 3.62, 70.

div2.head: Marcus Scaurus
div2.p: Aemilius, consul (115); partisan rather than statesman, 1.76.
ambassador to Jugurtha (112), notorious corruptionist, but loyal aristocrat; hence Cicero's praise, 1.108.

div2.head: Marcus Scaurus
div2.p: Aemilius, son of the preceding, stepson of Sulla, aedile (58) with extraordinary magnificence, 2.57.
governor of Sardinia (56), which he plundered outrageously; successfully defended by Cicero and Hortensius; later (52) condemned and banished, 1.138.

div2.head: Gnaeus Scipio
div2.p: Cornelius, brother of Publius (see following); consul (222) with Marcus Marcellus; with Publius in Spain (217-211); a gallant soldier, 1.61; 3.16.

div2.head: Publius Scipio
div2.p: Cornelius, brother of Gnaeus and father of the elder Africanus, 1.121.
consul (218), defeated by Hannibal at the Ticinus; waged war in Spain (217-211); a gallant soldier, 1.61; 3.16.

div2.head: Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus Major
div2.p: defeated Hannibal at Zama (202) and closed the war; never idle in his zeal for Rome, 3.1–4.

div2.head: Publius Scipio
div2.p: Cornelius, son of Africanus Major, adoptive father of Africanus Minor; gifted mentally but physically disqualified for an active career, 1.121.

div2.head: Publius Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus Africanus Minor
div2.p: adopted son of Publius Africanus's son, 1.121.
intimate friend of Laelius (q.v.) and devoted to literature; serious, earnest, 1.108.
at Pydna (168) with his father; captured and destroyed Carthage (146) and Numantia (133), 1.35; 2.76.
a statesman of high ideals, a bitter rival and yet a friend of Quintus Metellus, 1.87.

div2.head: Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica Serapio
div2.p: known chiefly as the man who led the riot and murdered Tiberius Gracchus, 1.76, 109.

div2.head: Publius Cornelius Scipio Nasica
div2.p: son of the preceding; died in his consulship (111); a charming gentleman and a brilliant speaker, 1.109.

div2.head: Marcus Seius
div2.p: reduced the price of corn and regained his lost popularity, 2.58.

div2.head: Sicily
div2.p: the great island south-west of Italy, fertile and rich, occupied along the coasts by prosperous Greek colonies, a Roman province (212 on), an easy prey for rapacious governors, as Verres whom Cicero prosecuted (70), 2.50.

div2.head: Sicyon
div2.p: a city near Corinth, famous as a centre of art; Aratus and the tyranny, 2.81–82.

div2.head: Decimus Silanus
div2.p: Junius, stepfather of Marcus Brutus, consul (62), aedile, 2.57.

div2.head: Socrates
div2.p: brilliant dialectician, with a profound meaning in every word, 1.108.
personal eccentricities, 1.148. The noblest, ay, and the wisest and most righteous man that we have ever known.

div2.head: Socratic
div2.p: most schools of philosophy are based on the teaching of Socrates-the Academy, 1.2.

div2.head: Solon
div2.p: the great lawgiver of Athens (638-658 ca.), poet, soldier, statesman; his feigned madness and the acquisition of Salamis, 1.108.
his constitution and the reorganized Areopagus, 1.75.

div2.head: Sophocles
div2.p: the great tragic poet (495-406), supreme on the Athenian stage (468-441); general in the war against Samos (440), 1.144.

div2.head: Sparta
div2.p: capital of Lacedaemon in the south-eastern part of the Peloponnesus, 3.99.
position at end of Persian wars, 1.76.

div2.head: Stoics
div2.p: adherents of the school founded by Zeno, an offshoot from Cynicism, 1.128.
refounded by Chrysippus; philosophy with them is practical, making life accord with Nature's laws, 3.13.
virtue and philosophy are identical; virtue the only good, 1.6; 3.11, 12.
no degrees of right or wrong, 1.10.

their right to teach ethics, 1.6;
Cicero adopts their teaching, 1.6; 3.20.
their theology a pantheistic materialism, God working in his providence, 3.102.

div2.head: Lucius Cornelius Sulla Felix
div2.p: (138-78), noble, profligate, brilliant genius; would stoop to anything, 1.109.
soldier against Jugurtha, Mithradates, Marius, Rome; statesman; reformed the constitution; absolute monarch of Rome (81-79); treatment of tributary allies, 3.87.

div2.head: Publius Sulla
div2.p: defended by Cicero on charge of complicity in Catiline's conspiracy.

div2.head: Gaius Sulpicius Galus
div2.p: predicted an eclipse of the moon.

div2.head: Publius Sulpicius Rufus
div2.p: (124-88), an eminent orator of little character, 2.49.

div2.head: Syracuse
div2.p: a great Greek city in south-eastern Sicily, rich in art and in goods; ruled by Dion, 1.155.

div2.head: Tantalus
div2.p: son of Zeus (Jupiter) and father of Pelops (q.v.), 3.84.

div2.head: Lucius Tarquinius Superbus
div2.p: the last king of Rome (535-510), a cruel tyrant, expelled by Brutus and Collatinus, 3.40.

div2.head: Tarquins
div2.p: the kinsmen of Tarquinius Superbus, all expelled (510), 3.40.

div2.head: Temperance
div2.p: essential to success; 2.77; vs. apparent Expediency, 3.116.

div2.head: Publius Terentius After
div2.p: (195-159), a comic poet, friend of Laelius and Scipio; six plays are left; quotation from the Heauton Timorumenus, 1.30.

div2.head: Thebe
div2.p: daughter of Jason and wife of Alexander of Pherae, 2.25.

div2.head: Thebes
div2.p: the capital of Boeotia, home of Pindar and Epaminondas, 1.155.

div2.head: Themistocles
div2.p: gave Athens her fleet and saved Greece at Salamis (480), 1.75.
not always scrupulous in his methods, 3.49.

div2.head: Theophrastus
div2.p: of Lesbos, favourite pupil and successor of Aristotle, a marvellous teacher, master of Demetrius of Phalerum, 1.3.

div2.head: Theopompus
div2.p: of Chios (fourth century), pupil of Isocrates, orator and historian, 2.40.

div2.head: Thermopylae
div2.p: a narrow pass on the seashore between Thessaly and Locris, held by Leonidas and his three hundred against the hosts of Xerxes (480), 1.61.

div2.head: Theseus
div2.p: the great legendary hero of Athens, benefactor of the world; uniter of Athens and Attica; father of Hippolytus (q.v.) by Antiope; husband of Phaedra; his son's death, 1.32; 3.94.

div2.head: Thrace
div2.p: the vast country north of the Aegean; though the home of Orpheus, Linus, etc., it was generally considered barbarous, 2.25.

div2.head: Thyestes
div2.p: son of Pelops and brother of Atreus (q.v.), (III, 102).

div2.head: Timotheus
div2.p: admiral of the Athenian fleet (378-356), compared with his father Conon, 1.116.

div2.head: Troezen
div2.p: a city of Argolis, near the shore opposite Aegina; the asylum of the Athenians at the approach of Xerxes, 3.48.

div2.head: Quintus Tubero
div2.p: Aelius, the Stoic, a pupil of Panaetius, praetor (123); a talented jurist, 3.63.

div2.head: Tusculum
div2.p: a town in the Alban hills the oldest municipium in Italy, admitted (381), 1.35.

div2.head: Twelve Tables
div2.p: the laws of, drawn up (450); quoted, 1.37; 3.111.

div2.head: Tyranny
div2.p: right and duty towards the tyrant, 3.19, 85.

div2.head: Tyre
div2.p: the great commercial city on the coast of Phoenice, 2.86.

div2.head: Ulysses
div2.p: (Odysseus), son of Laertes of Ithaca, the shrewdest of the Greek heroes at Troy, 3.97.

div2.head: Gaius Varro
div2.p: Terentius, consul (216) with Paulus, responsible for the disaster at Cannae, 3.114.

div2.head: Venus
div2.p: (Aphrodite), the goddess of beauty and love; of Cos, 3.10.

div2.head: Veseris
div2.p: a little stream near Mount Vesuvius; scene of the battle of Manlius Torquatus and the elder Decius, 3.112.

div2.head: Titus Veturius Calvinus
div2.p: consul with Spurius Postumius (321) at the Caudine Forks, 3.109.

div2.head: Vice
div2.p: by the criticism of the wise, 1.147.

div2.head: Volscians
div2.p: people of lower Latium, subdued (303), given full citizenship (188), 1.35.

div2.head: Theophrastus Wealth
div2.p: the real good of wealth, 2.56; see Riches.

div2.head: Wisdom
div2.p: the first of the Cardinal Virtues, 1.15–19.

div2.head: Xanthippus
div2.p: a Spartan soldier of fortune, whose generalship defeated Regulus, 3.99.

div2.head: Xenocrates
div2.p: of Chalcedon (396-314), a pupil of Plato, president of the Academy, industrious and severe, 1.109.

div2.head: Xerxes
div2.p: king of Persia (485-465), son of Darius, invaded Greece (480), came to grief at Salamis and Plataea, 3.48.

div2.head: Zeno
div2.p: of Cytium (fourth century), pupil of Crates the Cynic and founder of the Stoic school (see Stoics), 3.35.
